replies.msg:
dna replication is to replicate or copy dna. or one double helix to 2 double helices. this process likely happens in cell division or reproduction.

mRNA is a messager of course as it carries encoded information in dna. dna is transcripted into mRNA of particular gene. then mrna gets out of the nucleus and works wirh ribosomes and other cytoplasmic organelles to produce protein. then the protein is either utilized inside the cell or transported out thro cell membrane to be further processed for it's intended functions.

we can see mRNA can help to produce the needed protein and in this case the spike protein of coronavirus. the protein then incite needed immune responses.

however, the mRNA molecule is itself a macromolecule that can incite its own immune responses and other biological responses as well.

coronavirus and other rna virus actually carry a rna molecule not dna inside the protein coat of the virus particle. once infected, the viral rna will get into the cell and turn into a dna, then get into nucleus and potentially integrate that dna fragment into the host cell's dna body.

therefore, there are many spots in the whole viral life cycle to intercept the process to stop viral growth. but if considering vaccine approach the spike protein is picked.

found the answer

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15769613/
First-generation vectors were initially considered to be incapable of viral DNA replication, but it is necessary to delete one or more of the genes, all in the E2 transcription unit, that encode proteins essential for Ad DNA replication to completely eliminate viral DNA replication

Adenoviruses -- even as they occur in nature -- just do not have the capacity to alter DNA. Unlike retroviruses such as HIV or lentiviruses, wild-type adenoviruses do not carry the enzymatic machinery necessary for integration into the host cell's DNA.
